name: 3-hydroxybenzeneboronic acid
Reason: The basic unit for 3-hydroxybenzaldehyde is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The influence of the functional groups involved in 3-hydroxybenzeneboronic acid will shift the melting point relative to this base value. Firstly, the hydroxyl group (-OH) significantly increases the melting point due to hydrogen bonding capabilities; this effect can be approximated to a +100°C increase. Next, the boronic acid group (B(OH)2) further increases the melting point for similar reasons – hydrogen bonding and increased molecular complexity; the boronic acid group can be associated with an increase of about +70°C. Finally, there's a slight increase because of the additional phenolic OH, which we can estimate at +30°C. Combining these effects, we can predict a substantial net increase from the base value of benzene. It should be noted that these values are approximations and the actual shifts can vary based on molecular context.
